metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Investigate, qualitatively, the effect of current, external magnetic field and the number of loops of wire on the torque of a simple motor

torque_definition.name: Torque Definition
torque_definition.correct: Torque is the turning effect of a force, depending on both the force magnitude and its perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation.

the force acting on the coil.error: Force and torque are different quantities.
the force acting on the coil.fix: Force causes acceleration. Torque causes rotation. τ = rF.
the force acting on the coil.action: Identify the axis of rotation. Torque requires distance from that axis.

the speed of rotation.fix: Torque causes angular acceleration, not speed directly.
the speed of rotation.action: Greater torque means faster spin-up, not higher final speed.

the magnetic field strength.error: Field strength affects torque but is not torque itself.
the magnetic field strength.fix: B contributes to force, which contributes to torque. Not the same thing.
the magnetic field strength.action: Trace the chain: B → F → τ. Each is a different quantity.

persistent.gap: You're conflating cause and effect in rotational motion.
persistent.action: Draw the DC motor. Label force, lever arm, and axis. Torque = force × lever arm.

torque_force_relationship.name: Torque-Force Relationship
torque_force_relationship.correct: Torque is directly proportional to the magnetic force on the coil. Greater force means greater turning effect.

inversely proportional.fix: τ = rF. If F doubles, τ doubles.
inversely proportional.action: Push a door harder. Does it turn more or less easily?

independent of.fix: No force = no torque. More force = more torque.
independent of.action: τ = rF. Force is right there in the formula.

exponentially related.error: The relationship is linear, not exponential.
exponentially related.fix: Double the force, double the torque. Linear.
exponentially related.action: Check: τ = rF. No squares or exponentials present.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how torque depends on force.
persistent.action: Calculate torque for F = 1 N, 2 N, 3 N with same lever arm. See the pattern.

magnetic_force_formula.name: Magnetic Force on Coil
magnetic_force_formula.correct: The magnetic force on the coil depends on number of loops (n), field strength (B), current (I), and wire length (L).

F = BIL.fix: Each loop contributes force. More loops = more total force.
F = BIL.action: A coil with 10 loops has 10× the force of one loop.

F = nBI.error: Missing the length of wire in the field.
F = nBI.fix: Force depends on how much wire is in the field.
F = nBI.action: Longer wire in field = more force. L matters.

F = nBL.fix: No current = no force. I must be in the formula.
F = nBL.action: A wire with no current experiences no magnetic force.

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised the force formula.
persistent.action: Write F = nBIL ten times. Then explain what each variable means.

current_torque_relationship.name: Current-Torque Relationship
current_torque_relationship.correct: Increasing current increases the magnetic force on the coil, which increases torque. The relationship is directly proportional.

inversely proportional.fix: F = nBIL. Higher I means higher F, so higher torque.
inversely proportional.action: Turn up voltage on a motor. Does it spin faster or slower?

unrelated.error: Current directly affects the force, which affects torque.
unrelated.fix: Current is in the force formula: F = nBIL.
unrelated.action: No current means no force, so no torque.

quadratically related.error: The relationship is linear, not squared.
quadratically related.fix: I appears once in F = nBIL. Linear relationship.
quadratically related.action: Double I, double F, double τ. No squaring involved.

persistent.gap: You don't see how current flows through to torque.
persistent.action: Trace: I → F (via F = nBIL) → τ (via τ = rF). All linear.

field_strength_torque.name: Magnetic Field-Torque Relationship
field_strength_torque.correct: Increasing the external magnetic field strength increases the force on the coil, which increases torque.

inversely proportional.fix: F = nBIL. Bigger B means bigger F, so bigger τ.
inversely proportional.action: Stronger magnets make motors more powerful.

unrelated.error: Field strength directly affects the force.
unrelated.fix: B is in the force formula: F = nBIL.
unrelated.action: Remove the magnets from a motor. Does it still work?

affects direction only.error: Field affects both magnitude and direction.
affects direction only.fix: Stronger field = stronger force = greater torque.
affects direction only.action: Compare motors with weak vs strong magnets.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting field strength to force to torque.
persistent.action: Draw the chain: B ↑ → F ↑ (F = nBIL) → τ ↑ (τ = rF).

loops_torque_relationship.name: Number of Loops-Torque Relationship
loops_torque_relationship.correct: More loops of wire means more total force, which means more torque. Each loop contributes to the total force.

inversely proportional.fix: Each loop adds force. Total force = n × (force per loop).
inversely proportional.action: Compare a 1-loop and 100-loop motor. Which is more powerful?

unrelated.error: Number of loops directly affects total force.
unrelated.fix: n is in the force formula: F = nBIL.
unrelated.action: Think: 10 loops means 10× the wire, so 10× the force.

quadratically related.fix: n appears once in F = nBIL. Double n, double F.
quadratically related.action: Check the formula: F = nBIL. No n² anywhere.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how loops multiply the force.
persistent.action: Each loop is like adding another wire in the field. More wires = more total force.

torque_position_variation.name: Torque Variation with Position
torque_position_variation.correct: Torque is maximum when the coil is horizontal (parallel to field) and zero when vertical (perpendicular to field).

constant throughout rotation.error: Torque varies as the coil rotates.
constant throughout rotation.fix: Lever arm changes with angle. τ = rF sin θ.
constant throughout rotation.action: At vertical position, force acts through axis. No lever arm, no torque.

maximum when vertical.error: Reversed. Maximum torque occurs when horizontal.
maximum when vertical.fix: Horizontal = maximum lever arm. Vertical = zero lever arm.
maximum when vertical.action: Draw the coil vertical. Where does the force act relative to the axis?

zero when horizontal.fix: Horizontal = maximum perpendicular distance from axis.
zero when horizontal.action: Lever arm is longest when coil is horizontal.

persistent.gap: You're not visualising how lever arm changes with angle.
persistent.action: Draw the coil at 0°, 45°, 90°. Mark the lever arm in each case.

motor_starting_position.name: Motor Starting Position
motor_starting_position.correct: A DC motor starts most easily from the horizontal position where torque is maximum. It cannot start from vertical where torque is zero.

vertical position.error: Torque is zero when vertical. Motor cannot start there.
vertical position.fix: At vertical, force acts through the axis. No turning effect.
vertical position.action: Try opening a door by pushing at the hinge. Same problem.

any position.fix: The vertical position has zero torque. Cannot start there.
any position.action: Draw force at vertical position. It passes through the axis.

depends on current only.fix: Even high current gives zero torque at vertical position.
depends on current only.action: τ = rF sin θ. When θ = 0°, torque = 0 regardless of F.

persistent.gap: You don't understand dead spots in motors.
persistent.action: Find where sin θ = 0 in τ = rF sin θ. That's the dead spot.

increasing_motor_torque.name: Ways to Increase Motor Torque
increasing_motor_torque.formula: Increase n, B, I, or L
increasing_motor_torque.correct: Torque can be increased by increasing current, magnetic field strength, number of loops, or length of coil sides in the field.

increasing resistance.error: Higher resistance reduces current, reducing torque.
increasing resistance.fix: More resistance = less current = less force = less torque.
increasing resistance.action: V = IR. If R goes up, I goes down for same V.

decreasing current.error: Less current means less force and less torque.
decreasing current.fix: F = nBIL. Smaller I means smaller F.
decreasing current.action: Trace: I ↓ → F ↓ → τ ↓. All decrease together.

using weaker magnets.error: Weaker magnets mean less force and less torque.
using weaker magnets.fix: F = nBIL. Smaller B means smaller F.

persistent.gap: You're confusing what increases vs decreases torque.
persistent.action: Make a table: n↑, B↑, I↑, L↑ all increase torque. Their opposites decrease it.

motor_rotation_rate.name: Torque and Rotation Rate
motor_rotation_rate.correct: A motor with greater torque will accelerate faster and reach higher rotation rates, assuming the same load.

slower rotation.error: More torque = faster rotation, not slower.
slower rotation.fix: Torque causes angular acceleration. More torque = quicker spin-up.
slower rotation.action: Compare a weak and strong motor lifting the same weight.

same rotation rate.error: Torque directly affects how fast the motor accelerates.
same rotation rate.fix: Angular acceleration α = τ/I (moment of inertia).
same rotation rate.action: Higher torque means more angular acceleration.

depends only on voltage.error: Voltage affects current, which affects torque, which affects speed.
depends only on voltage.fix: V → I → F → τ → rotation rate. All connected.
depends only on voltage.action: Trace the full chain from voltage to rotation.

persistent.gap: You don't connect torque to rotational acceleration.
persistent.action: τ = Iα (rotational Newton's second law). More torque = more α.
